titleStmt.title: Definitions of all the Variations of the Word Cheap

sourceDesc.p: OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2015. Web. 21 November 2015.

head.title: Definitions of all Variations of Cheap - Organized by Parts of Speech

fs.f: To barter, buy and sell; to trade, deal, bargain.
c1000 West Saxon Gospels: Matt. (Corpus Cambr.) xxi. 12
intransitive
To bargain for, bid for, offer to buy, offer a price for, ask the price of, ‘price’.
c1400 ?c1390 Sir Gawain & Green Knight (1940) l. 1271
intransitive
To buy.
c950 The Lindisfarne Gospels John iv. 8
transitive
To bargain for, bid for, offer to buy, offer a price for, ask the price of, ‘price’.
?c1225 ?a1200 Ancrene Riwle (Cleo. C.vi) (1972) 214
transitive
To treat or bargain in order to sell, to offer for sale; also (with inf.) to offer to sell.
a1225 Juliana 63
transitive
To chaffer, haggle about terms with (a person), or about (a bargain).
1655 Ld. Orrery Parthenissa IV. ii. vi. 614
transitive
To fix the price of, set a price on, value.
a1464 J. Capgrave Abbreuiacion of Cron. (Cambr. Gg.4.12) (1983) 140
To become cheap (lit. and fig.).
intransitive
To bargain for, ask the price of, bid for, offer a price for; = cheap v. 3.
1574 E. Hellowes tr. A. de Guevara Familiar Epist. 200
transitive
To make cheap, lower the price of.
1833 H. Martineau French Wines & Politics viii. 125
transitive
To bargain, chaffer.
1620 F. Quarles Pentelogia (1717) 66
absolute
To lower in estimation, cause to be thought little of, bring into contempt, vilify.
1654 R. Whitlock Ζωοτομία 426
figurative
A bargain about the bartering or exchanging of one commodity for another, or of giving money or the like for any commodity; bargaining, trade, buying and selling.
OE Beowulf 2415
simple
The place of buying and selling; market.
c1000 Ælfric Gram. (Z.) xxxii. 201
simple
in place-names, as Cheapside, Eastcheap.
simple
That which is given in exchange for a commodity; price; value.
c1025 Cnut's Eccl. Laws 18 (Bosw.)
simple
Exchangeable commodities, merchandise, goods, chattels, esp. (live) cattle.
897 Anglo-Saxon Chron.
simple
Bargain, purchase; qualified from the buyer's point of view as good, great, etc., as in the modern ‘a good bargain’, ‘a great bargain’, ‘a bargain’, etc. Cf. French faire bon marché.
1340 Ayenbite (1866) 36
contextual

State of the market, qualified from the buyer's point of view as good, dear, etc. good cheap: a state of the market good for the purchaser; low prices, abundance of commodities, plenty, cheapness. So dear cheap: a dear market, high prices, dearth, scarcity.
c1325 Pol. Songs (Camden) 341
contextual
Plenty, abundance.
c1325 Coer de L. 1897
contextual
Abundance of commodities, plenty, cheapness; opposed to dearth.
c1384 Chaucer Hous of Fame 1974
contextual

good cheap was used for: That is a good bargain, that can be purchased on advantageous terms; low-priced, cheap. Compared better cheap, best cheap. So (rarely) great cheap. (It is not clear whether the notion was ‘at a good market’, or ‘as a good bargain’.)
contextual
c1375 Cato Major i. xxix, in Anglia (1884) VII
That costs little (trouble, etc.), easily obtained; plentiful, abundant; of small value, ‘cheap’.
contextual
good cheap was also used (cf. to or at good cheap in sense 5a) for: On advantageous terms, at a low cost, cheaply.
1420 Will & Inv. N. Counties (1835) 63
contextual
On good terms, with little effort; cheaply, easily.
1567–9 J. Jewel Def. Apol. Churche Eng. (1611) 461
contextual
That may be bought at small cost; bearing a relatively low price; inexpensive. Opposed to dear.
1517 S. Hawes Pastime of Pleasure (1928) iv. 24
(Applied to the price itself, the place where a commodity is sold, etc.) cheap fare: a fare at a lower rate than the ordinary fare; also cheap rate; also attrib.
1616 B. Jonson Every Man in his Humor (rev. ed.) i. i, in Wks. I. 7
Applied to money obtainable at a low rate of interest.
1861 Economist 23 Mar. 309/2
Bearing a low price in proportion to its intrinsic value; of good value in proportion to its price; well worth the price.
1611 T. Middleton & T. Dekker Roaring Girle sig. B3
Costing little labour, trouble, effort, etc.; easily obtained.
a1616 Shakespeare Measure for Measure (1623) ii. iv. 106
Involving little trouble and hence of little worth; worthless, paltry.
a1604 M. Hanmer Chron. Ireland 63 in J. Ware Two Hist. Ireland (1633)
In poor health; out of sorts. (Hence cheapness.) slang.
1891 J. S. Farmer Slang
Accounted of small value, made little of, lightly esteemed; esp. brought into contempt through being made too familiar.
1597 Bacon Of Ceremonies & Respectes in Essaies sig. B4
to hold cheap: to hold of small account, think little of, despise.
a1616 Shakespeare Comedy of Errors (1623) iii. i. 21
Low, poor, disparaging.
1907 M. C. Harris Tents of Wickedness iii. iii. 250

Phr. as cheap as dirt: exceedingly cheap(ly) (colloq.); hence dirt-cheap adj., q.v. Cf. the earlier dog cheap adj. to be cheap of a thing (Sc.): not to be over-paid in respect of, to get less than one's deserts (in the way of retribution, etc.). So to be cheap served.
a1817 J. Austen Persuasion (1818) IV. ix. 190
At a low price, at small expense, cheaply; with little trouble, easily.
1569 R. Grafton Chron. II. 355
